bibl.title: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Henry Rose Carter to J. Gil Cardenas, July 23, 1920

div1.p: Carter informs Cardenas about the sanitary conditions in the department of Piura, Peru.

div1.head: English translation [from Spanish] of letter from Henry Rose Carter to J. Gil Cardenas, July 23, 1920 (See Spanish original.)
div1.opener:
Survey made from June 28 to July 19
Lima, Perú,
July 23th., 1920.
Peru
Report
Dr. Joseph Gil Cárdenas,
Director of Public Health.
Lima.
Dear sir;
div1.p:
I have the honor to submit the following report on the
sanitary condition of the department of Piura as regard yellow fe-
ver.

"Let me begin by saying that the probability of yellow fe-
ver spreading in any community in which it exists and into which
it is introduced depends on (1) the numbers of active stegomyia
present and (2) on the proportion of people susceptible to yellow
fever; i.e. on the amount of fever which has previously occurred in
the community.

Hence the fever is most apt to occur and spread next summer in
towns in which there have been few cases last summer naturally if
introduced into towns in which no cases have occurred it would find
virgin soil. A town in which only few cases occurred and reporting fever in June
or later needs watching.

The problem naturally divids itself geographycally into:
(1) The district on the line of Rail Road from Payta to Piura
and Catacaos.
(2) The valley of the Piura-below Catacaos.
(3) The valley of the Piura-above Piura; the Valley of Morropón.

The division is not sharp as Sullana: Piura and Catacaos are rather
closely connected in their travel-relations with the Morropón Valley and,
to a less extent, the last two with the valley of the lower Piura.
Those three towns, Piura and Catacaos especially, are the key to the
situation in this department.

(1).- Not only has no yellow fever beeb reported in Payta for three
months but I am sure none exists here and I have made rather a care
ful inspection. Drs. Reinoso and Zúñiga state that thay see no sickness
except a small amount of Grippe.

The inspection for larvae is well carried out. Not only do the records
show a very small percentage of houses as breeding stegomyia, but the
work done corresponds with the records. I went around with the Visita-
dors and can assert this. The water supply too has been greatly im-
proved making this work easier.

The records show that from July 1st. to 8th. inclusive 780 houses exa
mined, yielded 18 depositos with larvae-nearly all of which were small
and in only 2 cases were ninfas found. From July 9th. to 16th. of 645
houses only 5 showed larvae; in only one case large and no ninfas.

The first gives index of 2.3% and the second of less 4/5 of 1%
The “Index of Production”-larvae and ninfas- is much smaller in both
cases than the above. Payta at present and as long as the production
of stegomyia in kept at this level, is not infectable with yellow fe-
ver and as long as these conditions hold it seems to me unnecessary
to continue the quarantine against it for yellow fever.

These has been no yellow fever reported since March or early April
on the Lime of the Rail Road between Payta and Piura and considering
the rather sharp epidemics in La Huaca and Tamarindo-both small pla-
ces-last summer and the anti-stegomyia work done in these places,
they at least would not be expected to show any at this time. Sullana
is a larger place and had no great deal of fever last summer. Yet my
examination showed the number of stegomyia produced to be small. The
anti-stegomyia work was quite good and the facility with which water
is obtain here makes the work easy and efficient.

No cases of yellow fever have been reported as contracted in Piura or
Catacaos since April; although two cases developed in the Carcel in
Piura in May. Dr. Vega is of the opinion that these were contracted in
Chulucanas, which is probable but not entirely certain. The stegomyia
index in Piura was low in April last-the water supply renders the
work fairly easy-and with the cool weather is naturally lower now. It
is an important place and, with Catacaos and Sullana, I consider it
the key to the yellow fever situation in this department. The anti-ste-
gomyia work should be continued and pressed to the limit at this place
ao that if fever be still present (I feel quite sure it is not)
or reintroduced in the early summer it will not spread.

Catacaos is probably free from yellow fever but it is a place with
much Malaria, which confuses diagnosis, and, as many of the sick, recover
or died without being seen by a physician, it is not easy to judge
what sickness may, or may not, be there.

The records of the stegomyia work are favorable although far less so
than at Payta. Such an inspection as I was able to make, with three Vi-
sitadors only, was less encouraging. The actual work was less good than
the records would indicate. Capt. Mitchel was given my findings and direc-
ted to pay particular attention to this place as soon as he could vi-
sit it and to remedy the defects found. A first class Chief of Visi-
tadores is needed here; the one who was here has been moved to Tumbes.

I believe the main difficulty to efficient stegomyia control here is
the problem of “Casas cerradas”. This is trouble-some enough every
where, even in Payta, but owing to the multitude of fiestas and the ha-
bits of the population is especially difficult in Catacaos.

(2).-In the lower Piura valley yellow fever was reported in June (1st.
and 8th.) by Dr. Caballero and Saona. None has been reported since
that date and as the place is small. There is the reason to hope that
there has been none since. My advice was of the July 9th..There is
however much Paludismo here which naturally confuses diagnosis.

None has been reported from Sechura or Vice for a much longer a time
and Dr. Caballero-who visited Sechura July 10th-reported no sickness
of any kind at that place. This too is an important place as the tra-
vel south into Lambayeque-with fish and for grain-would infect that
country if Sechura be infected.

The anti-stegomyia work in this district below Catacaos is directed
by Sabns, selected as being an unuusually efficient man. I have not
seen it. Mitchel was directed to visit this district ans pay attention
to it, especially to Muñuela.

There is no graduated physician living in this district-below Catacaos
ans it is advisable that such a man he stationed here for diagnostic
purposes-say-at Sechura. The Practicante Saona at Muñuela is I belie-
ve an unusually well-informed man. Dr. Chipoco was advised to return
to Sechura and assume medical (diagnostic) supervision of this district.

(3).- I did not visit the Morropón Valley. Had made arrangments to do
so, but owing to delays this was not possible without unduly postpo-
ning my visit to Lima. I saw however the physicians Valcarcel, Mendoza
- 3 -
and Chipoco, who has been stationed there and Capt. Mitchel, who, with Dr.
Chipoco came into Piura the Sunday before I left. No fever reported at
Tambogrande (Valcarcel) since June 16th.-20 cases seen there with 5
deaths. None in Chulucanas (mendoza) since June 28th. He left Chulucanas
July 3th. None reported at Morropón for a long time; in April or early
part of May I think-I have lost the record-and, considering the rather
sharp epidemic earlier in the season and the vigorous anti-stegomyia
campaign begin in April, there should be none now. Mitchel was returning
from the inspection of a numbers of a small places between Piura, Tambo
grande, Chulucanas, Morropón and Salitral and reported the stegomyia
work good at Chulucanas. It is under Reyes and Velasco who are considered
good men. That at Tambogrande was not so good and the Chief of Visitadors
there was changed.

Of this valley the key is Chulucanas. It is (1) a large town- 10000 popu-
lation; (2) a commercail centre, from and to which there is a considera-
ble travel; (3) no such considerable amount of fever has been reported
here as at either Morropón or Tambogrande; although doubtless more occu-
rred than has been reported and (4) fever has been reported quite recently.
Intensive and continued stegomyia work is advisable here and naturally
the same should be continued at Tambogrande and Morropón.

There is no graduated physician living in this district-the empírico
Cruz rendering it medical assistance-and it seems advisable that a
physician be stationed at Chulucanas-which lies between Morropón and
Tambogrande-who could perform the diagnostic work needed in both of
these towns as well as in Chulucanas. There is much Paludismo in this
valley-especially about Morropón-tending to obscure diagnosis. It was
advised that Dr. Mendoza return to Chulucanas.

list.item:
(1).-That yellow fever has disappeared from most of the department of
Piura, quite certainly from Payta and probably from the other places
on the line of the Rail Road.

(2).-That the infection of this disease probably still lingers in same
places in this department:Chulucanas, Muñuela and Tambogrande being , es-
pecially to the suspected.

(3).-That pressing the campaign against the stegomyia during the pre-
sent winter should result in the elimination of this infection and is
therefore extremely advisable.

(4).-This work (stegomyia) should be continued at Payta and the group of
towns, Piura; Catacaos and Sullana, and pressed to the limit in Chuluca-
nas, Muñuela and Tambogrande.

(5).This work requires constant supervision by a highly traied Inspector.
Indeed I do not believe one man can give the supervision required. Very
obviously our success in this campaign depends primarily on the stego-
myia work and hence on the Inspectors.

(6).-There should be organized a service in excess of ordinary needs-of
two or more Visitadores and their gangs-to be quickly moved to any pla-
ce in which especially quicky and intensive stegomyia work is needed.
This is the so called “Brigada Volante” we have used in other countries (
(Brazil ans Central América). Its personnel can be drawn from the other
towns in which work is being done. It is especially disireable that
this Brigada be avaible as the summer comes on: although I hope it may
not needed.

div1.p: Three things I would invite your attention.

(1-) There is believed to be no yellow fever in any place on the Pacific
Coast of South América, except in Piura and Guayaquil. When this is eli-
- 4 -
minated the whole of this coast will be free. Panamá and Guayaquil,
the sources od so many Paruvian epidemics, being no longer able to con
taminated us should remain free.

(2) The trade relations of this coast are such that vessels do not
pass directly from ports north of Panamá to those South of its passing
into Balboa instead and the Isthmus Isthmus, instead of the menace is has been
to us in past, is now a protection.

(3) The Coast south of the Canal then is not exposed to infection from
such Mexican and Central American foci of infection as still exist;
but if once freed from this infection completely, should remain perma -
nently free.

I confidently expect the complete elimination of yellow fever from the
Americas before it could reach our Pacific Coast by any indirect means.
On the other hand if the fever recrudesces and spreads next season, these
re is chance of the recontaminatiom of Guayaquil which would again beco-
me a menace to Perú and also of extension into the populous districts
around Chiclayo in Lamabayeque; against which extension measures were,
very wisely, taken last summer.

If introduced into this district and spread, its elimination would be
costly and difficult with a possibility of forming a focus more or less
lasting- for which the conditions are not unprovable. At any rate the
some-what costly stegomyia work done last summer in this district would
have be repeated.

These considerations to my mind render it advisable to press the work
to render the complete elimination of yellow fever from Piura certain.
This should be done now while the temperature is less favorable for ste-
gomyia production. It is fair say in Piura the temperature is by no means
so low as it is in Lima and yet the great epidemic in Lima, if I remem-
ber aright lasted over the Winter and recrudesced the next Summer dying
out I judge from exhaustion of the human material.
